facts.text: Appeals by certificate from High Court judgment dated 31 March, 1969.

facts.text: Appeals arise out of special cases No. 16 and 16A of 1964 pending before Special Judge, Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: These three appeals arise out of special cases No. 16 and 16A of 1964 pending in the companyrt of the Special Judge, Gauhati.

facts.text: In Special Case No. 16 of 1964, Major J. S. Prosad, N. Ananthapadamanabhiah and Motiur Rahman charged under section 120B IPC r/w sections 5(2), 5(1)(c) and 5(1)(d) PC Act and 467/471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: In Special Case No. 16 of 1964 Major J. S. Prosad, N. Ananthapadamanabhiah and Motiur Rahman were charged under section 120B of the Indian Pencil Code read with sections 5 2 , 5 1   c  and 5 1  d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act, 1947 and section 467/ 471 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: In Special Case No. 16A of 1964, charges framed against S. Chatterjee and Motiur Rehman under section 120B IPC r/w sections 5(2), 5(1)(c), 5(1)(d) PC Act and 467/471 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: In Special Case No. 16A of 1964 charges were framed against S. Chatterjee and Motiur Rehman under section 120B of the Indian Penal Code read with sections 5 2 , 5 1  c  and 5 1  d  of the Prevention of Corruption Act and sections 467 and 471 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellants filed three separate criminal revision petitions in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants filed three separate criminal revision petitions in the High Court.

facts.text: Four contentions advanced before High Court by appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Four companytentions were advanced before the High Court.

facts.text: First contention: Special Judge at Gauhati had no jurisdiction as Delhi Special Police Establishment Act not extended to NEFA.

anchor.surface_text: First, that the Special Judge at Gauhati had numberjurisdiction to try offences investigated by the Delhi Special Police Establishment as the Delhi Special Establishment.Act was number extended to NEFA.

facts.text: Second contention: No consent of Assam Government under section 6 of Delhi Special Police Establishment Act.

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, that under section 6 of the Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, the Delhi Special Police Establishment cannot investigate in a case in any area which is number a Union territory or a railway area without the companysent of the Government of the State. It was companytended that the companysent of the Government of Assam was number taken.

facts.text: Third contention: Investigation by Inspector of Police under order of First-class Magistrate at Delhi, but Magistrate did not apply mind.

anchor.surface_text: Thirdly, the investigation was carried out by an Inspector of Police under section 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act under an order of a Magistrate of the First-class at Delhi but the Magistrate did number apply his mind to the matter and mechanically gave the permission.

facts.text: Fourth contention: No sanction under section 196A CrPC before cognizance taken by court.

anchor.surface_text: Fourthly, numbersanction was taken under section 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure before companynisance was taken by the companyrt.

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court (C.J. and Goswami J.) unanimously rejected first two contentions, divided on third and fourth.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench companysisting of C. J. and Goswami, J. unanimously rejected the first two companytentions but were divided in their opinion as to whether the Magistrate applied. his mind. to allow the investigation by an Inspector of Police and whether sanction under section 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure was necessary.

facts.text: Matter placed before third Judge Sen J.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was thereafter placed before the third learned Judge Sen, J.

facts.text: Before third Judge, contention that Delhi Magistrate had no jurisdiction to accord sanction to DSPE Inspector for investigation in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: Before the third learned Judge another companytention was advanced as to whether the Magistrate at Delhi.had jurisdiction to accord sanction to an Inspector of Police of the Delhi Special Police Establishment to investigate the case in Assam.

facts.text: Third Judge held that order of local jurisdiction Magistrate necessary, Delhi Magistrate not competent, did not apply mind, quashed proceedings before Special Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The third learned Judge held that. an order of a Magistrate of the local jurisdiction was necessary and excepting a Magistrate of the district where the crime was companymitted numberother Magistrate outside the jurisdiction companyld make an order for investigation The third learned Judge also held that the Magistrate at Delhi did number apply his mind to allow the inspector of. police to do the investigation In the result, the proceedings before the Special Judge were quashed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that under section 429 CrPC, third Judge can deal with whole case.

anchor.surface_text: This Court held that the third learned Judge companyld deal with the whole case. The language of section 429 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is explicit that the case with the opinion of the Judges companyprising the Court of Appeal shall be laid before another Judge of the same Court.

facts.text: Investigation carried out by Inspector of Delhi Special Police Establishment under order of First Class Magistrate at Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: the investigation was carried out by an Inspector of Police under section 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act under an order of a Magistrate of the First-class at Delhi

facts.text: Supreme Court held Delhi Magistrate not competent to authorise investigation for cases in Assam under section 5A Prevention of Corruption Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeals, the order of investigation made by the Magistrate at Delhi for investigation of cases in the State of Assam was number a valid and companypetent order within the powers of the Magistrate at Delhi. These orders of investigation are therefore rightly quashed by the High Court.

facts.text: High Court quashed proceedings before Special Judge.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the proceedings before the Special Judge were quashed.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld quashing of investigation orders by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: These orders of investigation are therefore rightly quashed by the High Court. arguments.claim: Presidency Magistrates and first class Magistrates have territorial jurisdiction limited to their presidency towns or districts per CrPC ss6,10,12,18,32; Delhi Magistrate cannot order investigation in Assam.

anchor.surface_text: Presidency Magistrate under sections 6 and 18 of the Code of Criminal Procedure are for each of the Presidency towns. A Presidency Magistrate exercises jurisdiction within the presidency towns... It therefore follows that the Magistrates of the first class of a district have powers within defined local areas within the district

arguments.claim: Section 5A PC Act requires order from local Presidency or first class Magistrate to protect against frivolous prosecutions; appropriate that local Magistrates order investigations within their jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: The real import of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act is that investigation is to be done by Police Officers of a certain rank to ensure protection against frivolous prosecution and it is only with the order of Presidency Magistrate or a Magistrate of the first class that Police Officers below the rank mentioned in the section are allowed to investigate.

holdings.text: The third learned Judge could deal with the whole case under section 429 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, and the judgment follows the opinion of the third Judge.

anchor.surface_text: This Court held that the third learned Judge could deal with the whole case. The language of section 429 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is explicit that the case with the opinion of the Judges comprising the Court of Appeal shall be laid before another Judge of the same Court. The other noticeable feature in section 429 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is that the judgment or order shall follow the opinion of the third learned Judge.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit language of section 429 CrPC requires the case to be laid before another Judge who deals with the whole case; follows precedent in Hethubha Ors. v. State of Gujarat.

holdings.text: A Magistrate at Delhi lacks territorial jurisdiction to authorise investigation under section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act for offences in the State of Assam.

anchor.surface_text: Presidency Magistrate under sections 6 and 18 of the Code of Criminal Procedure are for each of the Presidency towns. A Presidency Magistrate exercises jurisdiction within the presidency towns for which he is appointed and within the limits of the port of such town. Magistrates of the first class are dealt with under sections 6, 10, 11, 12 and 13 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and their powers of sentence are dealt with by section 32 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 5A PC Act read harmoniously with CrPC sections 6, 10, 12, 18 defining territorial jurisdiction of Presidency Magistrates (limited to presidency towns) and first class Magistrates (district or defined local areas, extendable throughout district); Magistrate must have power to inquire or try the case locally.

holdings.text: The order of investigation made by the Magistrate at Delhi for cases in Assam was not valid and competent; such orders rightly quashed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeals, the order of investigation made by the Magistrate at Delhi for investigation of cases in the State of Assam was not a valid and competent order within the powers of the Magistrate at Delhi. These orders of investigation are therefore rightly quashed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of territorial jurisdiction principle under s5A PC Act and CrPC; Delhi Magistrate lacks competence for Assam cases.

holdings.text: Under section 5A PC Act, first class Magistrates exercise jurisdiction throughout the district irrespective of defined local areas under s12(1) CrPC by virtue of s12(2).

anchor.surface_text: The effect of section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act is that it is a special Act which confers powers on Presidency Magistrates exercisable throughout the Presidency town and Magistrates of the first class throughout the District where they exercise powers under the Code of Criminal Procedure. Ordinarily, Magistrates of the first class may have defined areas within the meaning of section 12(1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure but in cases governed by section 5A of the Prevention of Corruption Act, Magistrates of the first class will exercise jurisdiction throughout the district irrespective of defined areas of their jurisdiction within that district by reason of section 12(2) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s5A PC Act confers powers within CrPC framework; s12(2) extends jurisdiction throughout district for such cases.

holdings.text: No need to decide whether the Delhi Magistrate applied his mind, as he lacked competence to authorise investigation.

anchor.surface_text: The contention on behalf of the appellants that the order of the Magistrate allowing the Inspector of Police to investigate was proper and that he applied his mind is not required to be gone into in the present appeals in view of the decision that the Magistrate at Delhi was not competent to authorise the investigation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue rendered academic by finding of lack of jurisdiction.

holdings.text: No need to decide whether sanction under section 196A CrPC was necessary before cognizance.

anchor.surface_text: It is also not necessary to express any opinion on the other contention as to whether sanction under section 196A of the Code of Criminal Procedure was necessary before the courts could take cognizance of the matter.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not required due to invalid investigation.

holdings.text: The order of the Magistrate at Delhi is not a valid and proper order and therefore the investigation was bad.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that the order of the Magistrate at Delhi is not a valid and proper order and therefore the investigation was bad.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Consequence of lack of territorial jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: This Court held that the third learned Judge could deal with the whole case. The language of section 429 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is explicit that the case with the opinion of the Judges comprising the Court of Appeal shall be laid before another Judge of the same Court. The other noticeable feature in section 429 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is that the judgment or order shall follow the opinion of the third learned Judge.

These orders of investigation are therefore rightly quashed by the High Court. The contention on behalf of the appellants that the order of the Magistrate allowing the Inspector of Police to investigate was proper and that he applied his mind is not required to be gone into in the present appeals in view of the decision that the Magistrate at Delhi was not competent to authorise the investigation.

anchor.surface_text: Presidency Magistrate under sections 6 and 18 of the Code of Criminal Procedure are for each of the Presidency towns. A Presidency Magistrate exercises jurisdiction within the presidency towns for which he is appointed and within the limits of the port of such town. Magistrates of the first class are dealt with under sections 6, 10, 11, 12 and 13 of the Code of Criminal Procedure and their powers of sentence are dealt with by section 32 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

These orders of investigation are therefore rightly quashed by the High Court.
